sentence.text: Nature can be calm and beautiful, like a forest, a flower, or a sunset.
But sometimes, nature can be violent and produce natural disasters that kill many people.
In these chapters, you will learn about disasters caused by the ground moving and by strong winds.
When the ground moves, it causes earthquakes, tsunamis, and some volcanoes.
Strong winds can cause tornados that destroy buildings and can also kill people.
The picture shows how the earth looked 300 million years ago.
The yellow part moved away and became Africa.
But why did it move?
The land we live on, and even the land under the oceans, are like plates on top of a layer of very, very hot rock inside the earth.
The picture shows how the earth looked 300 million years ago.
The yellow part moved away and became Africa.
But why did it move?
The land we live on, and even the land under the oceans, are like plates on top of a layer of very, very hot rock inside the earth.
The layer of hot rock is called the mantle.
The heat makes the mantle slowly spin, and that makes the plates on top move.
The red plate drifted away and became India.
Then it hit the pink plate that became Asia.
The India plate pushed hard and went under the Asia plate, which lifted up the land and made mountains.
These are the Himalaya Mountains, the tallest in the world.
The layer of hot rock is called the mantle.
The heat makes the mantle slowly spin, and that makes the plates on top move.
The red plate drifted away and became India.
Then it hit the pink plate that became Asia.
The India plate pushed hard and went under the Asia plate, which lifted up the land and made mountains.
These are the Himalaya Mountains, the tallest in the world.
Instead of sliding under, sometimes plates slide past each other.
The small brown plate became part of California, and it is sliding past the big brown plate that became the rest of North America.
If you slide the small brown plate up a little bit, you will see how California is still moving!.
Because the plates are still moving, they cause some types of natural disasters that you will read about.
Instead of sliding under, sometimes plates slide past each other.
The small brown plate became part of California, and it is sliding past the big brown plate that became the rest of North America.
If you slide the small brown plate up a little bit, you will see how California is still moving!.
Because the plates are still moving, they cause some types of natural disasters that you will read about.
The ground shakes and slides…the buildings move….
It's an earthquake! Why do earthquakes happen?
The plates on top of the mantle move, and this movement is called plate tectonics.
Plate tectonics causes earthquakes.
The ground shakes and slides…the buildings move….
It's an earthquake! Why do earthquakes happen?
The plates on top of the mantle move, and this movement is called plate tectonics.
Plate tectonics causes earthquakes.
The plates on top of the mantle move.
This movement is called plate tectonics.
Plate tectonics causes earthquakes.
Plate tectonics is the name for the movement of plates on top of the mantle, and it is this movement that causes earthquakes.
Sometimes when plates slide past each other, parts become stuck.
If you try to slide the little brown plate, California, past the big brown plate, North America, it won't move much.
But the plates still push on each other and pressure builds.
A fault line is the place where plates push on each other.
Sometimes when plates slide past each other, parts become stuck.
If you try to slide the little brown plate, California, past the big brown plate, North America, it won't move much.
But the plates still push on each other and pressure builds.
A fault line is the place where plates push on each other.
Then, because of the pressure at the fault line, part of the little brown plate moves suddenly...BOOM!
The ground on one side of the fault line slides past the ground on the other side, and that sudden movement is an earthquake.
Buildings that are near a fault line can fall down when the plates move.
When that happens, there can be fires, and many people can be hurt.
Then, because of the pressure at the fault line, part of the little brown plate moves suddenly...BOOM!
The ground on one side of the fault line slides past the ground on the other side, and that sudden movement is an earthquake.
Buildings that are near a fault line can fall down when the plates move.
When that happens, there can be fires, and many people can be hurt.
Then the pressure at the fault line makes part of the little brown plate move suddenly…BOOM!
This sudden movement is an earthquake.
The ground on one side of the fault line slides past the ground on the other side.
There can be fires when that happens.
Many people can be hurt.
A tsunami is a giant wave that can cause a lot of damage.
A tsunami near India killed more than 200,000 people in 2004.
The picture shows two plates pushing under the ocean.
Over many, many years, the pushing causes a bulge in the plate.
A tsunami is a giant wave that can cause a lot of damage.
A tsunami near India killed more than 200,000 people in 2004.
The picture shows two plates pushing under the ocean.
Over many, many years, the pushing causes a bulge in the plate.
A tsunami is a giant wave.
It can cause a lot of damage.
A tsunami, which is a giant wave, can cause a lot of damage.
In 2004, a tsunami near India killed more than 200,000 people.
The picture shows two plates pushing under the ocean, which over many years, causes a bulge in the plate.
Sometimes, there is a sudden earthquake under the water when the bottom plate slides quickly under the top plate.
When that happens, there is a hole under the water, and water rushes in from all around to fill up the hole.
Water even rushes into the hole from near the shore, and that is called a drawback.
The drawback makes it look like the ocean is moving away from the land!
Sometimes, there is a sudden earthquake under the water when the bottom plate slides quickly under the top plate.
When that happens, there is a hole under the water, and water rushes in from all around to fill up the hole.
Water even rushes into the hole from near the shore, and that is called a drawback.
The drawback makes it look like the ocean is moving away from the land!
Sometimes, there is a sudden earthquake under the water.
This happens when the bottom plate slides quickly under the top plate.
When that happens, there is a hole under the water.
Water rushes in from all around to fill up the hole.
Water even rushes into the hole from near the shore.
That is called a drawback.
Sometimes, there is a sudden earthquake under the water that is made when the bottom plate slides quickly under the top plate.
But all of that extra water forms a huge wave.
The wave moves towards the shore, and when it gets close, it can grow to 100 feet tall and cover the buildings!
After the wave passes, there is another drawback, and the water rushes back to the ocean.
The drawback can carry people, animals, and buildings into the ocean.
The wave moves towards the shore, and when it gets close, it can grow to 100 feet tall and cover the buildings!
After the wave passes, there is another drawback, and the water rushes back to the ocean.
The drawback can carry people, animals, and buildings into the ocean.
There is a drawback after the wave passes.
The water rushes back to the ocean.
But all of that extra water forms a huge wave.
When all of that extra water gets close to the shore, it forms a huge wave, as tall as 100 feet, and can cover the buildings!
If you are near the ocean and see the water disappear, or if you hear a tsunami warning, you should climb up high to escape the wave and the drawback.
If you are near the ocean and see the water disappear, or if you hear a tsunami warning, you should climb up high to escape the wave and the drawback.
You should climb up high if you are near the ocean and you see the water disappear or hear a tsunami warning.
You will escape the wave and the drawback.

story.title: Volcanoes and the Making of Hawaii

sentence.text: Volcanoes spew out hot, melted rock from within the earth.
The melted rock is called lava.
Volcanoes are often found where plates meet, but sometimes a hotspot lets lava spew up in the middle of a plate.
The islands of Hawai'i were formed by the Pacific plate moving over a hotspot.
The lava moves up the plume from the mantle deep in the earth.
Volcanoes spew out hot, melted rock from within the earth.
The melted rock is called lava.
Volcanoes are often found where plates meet, but sometimes a hotspot lets lava spew up in the middle of a plate.
The islands of Hawai'i were formed by the Pacific plate moving over a hotspot.
The lava moves up the plume from the mantle deep in the earth.
Volcanoes are often found where plates meet.
Sometimes a hotspot lets lava spew up in the middle of a plate.
A plume of lava is in the mantle deep in the earth.
Lava moves up the plume.
Volcanoes spew out hot, melted rock, which is called lava, from deep in the earth.

story.title: Volcanoes and the Making of Hawaii

sentence.text: When the lava hits the ocean, it cools off and becomes rock.
Then, more and more lava moves up.
As lava forms enough rocks, the volcano makes an island.
The picture shows the Hawaiian island of Kaua'i that was made about five million years ago.
When the lava hits the ocean, it cools off and becomes rock.
Then, more and more lava moves up.
As lava forms enough rocks, the volcano makes an island.
The picture shows the Hawaiian island of Kaua'i that was made about five million years ago.
The lava hits the ocean.
There, it cools off and becomes rock.
Then more and more lava moves up.
The volcano makes an island after lava forms enough rocks.
The picture shows the Hawaiian island of Kaua'i.
It was made about five million years ago.
When more and more lava moves up, it forms enough rocks for the volcano to make an island.

story.title: Volcanoes and the Making of Hawaii

sentence.text: But remember, the Pacific plate is moving to the left in the picture.
After the plate moves, the plume spews up lava to form a new island.
This is the island of Oahu that was made about three million years ago.
But remember, the Pacific plate is moving to the left in the picture.
After the plate moves, the plume spews up lava to form a new island.
This is the island of Oahu that was made about three million years ago.
But remember, the Pacific plate is moving.
It moves to the left in the picture.

story.title: Volcanoes and the Making of Hawaii

sentence.text: The Pacific plate kept moving and made all of the other Hawaiian Islands.
The plume is still there, and it is adding rock to the Big Island (also called Hawai'i).
The Pacific plate kept moving and made all of the other Hawaiian Islands.
The plume is still there, and it is adding rock to the Big Island (also called Hawai'i).
The Pacific plate kept moving.
It made all of the other Hawaiian islands.
The plume is still there.
It is adding rock to the Big Island (also called Hawai'i).
The Pacific plate kept moving, which is what made all of the other Hawaiian Islands.
There is still a plume that is adding rock to the big island (also called Hawai'i).

story.title: Volcanoes and the Making of Hawaii

sentence.text: Visitors to Hawai'i can see the lava coming to the top of the volcano and making the island bigger.
But the lava can also destroy buildings and roads, and hot gases from volcanoes can kill people.
Visitors to Hawai'i can see the lava coming to the top of the volcano and making the island bigger.
But the lava can also destroy buildings and roads, and hot gases from volcanoes can kill people.
But, the lava can destroy buildings and roads.
Hot gases from volcanoes can also kill people.
Tornados are large, rapidly swirling columns of air.
Tornados start as a very large rain cloud called a supercell.
Some of the cool air (the blue arrow) starts to spin in the cloud.
Then, rain from the cloud drags down the spinning cool air.
Tornados are large, rapidly swirling columns of air.
Tornados start as a very large rain cloud called a supercell.
Some of the cool air (the blue arrow) starts to spin in the cloud.
Then, rain from the cloud drags down the spinning cool air.
Tornados are large, rapidly swirling columns of air.
Tornados start as a very large rain cloud.
This rain cloud is called a supercell.
Tornados are large, rapidly swirling columns of air that start as a very large rain cloud called a supercell.
Air near the ground is warm (the red arrow) and starts to rise in front of the spinning cool air.
The rising warm air also pulls in dirt that helps you see the swirling air.
As the tornado develops, the air swirls very fast, as fast as 300 miles per hour!
When a large tornado moves near a house, it can pull off the roof and cause a lot of damage.
Air near the ground is warm (the red arrow) and starts to rise in front of the spinning cool air.
The rising warm air also pulls in dirt that helps you see the swirling air.
As the tornado develops, the air swirls very fast, as fast as 300 miles per hour!
When a large tornado moves near a house, it can pull off the roof and cause a lot of damage.
Air near the ground is warm (the red arrow).
It starts to rise in front of the spinning cool air.
The rising warm air also pulls in dirt.
The dirt helps you see the swirling air.
The air swirls very fast as the tornado develops.
It can swirl as fast as 300 miles per hour!
Air near the ground is warm (the red arrow), which starts to rise in front of the spinning cool air.
After awhile, the cool air in the back of the tornado moves toward the front.
Then, the cool air blocks the warm air, and that causes the tornado to shrink.
Some tornados can last for hours and destroy many buildings.
Fortunately, most tornados last just a few minutes, although they can still cause serious damage.
